titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Tamiment staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-07-08T16:05-0400

change.item: Edited by Bonnie Gordon for compliance with DACS and Tamiment Required Elements for Archival Description and to include description of unprocessed materials.

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

physdesc.extent: in eight record cartons and one manuscript box.

did.abstract: This collection principally consists of printed ephemera from left rank and file caucuses within labor unions in the United States and other Anglophone countries from the late 1960s through the early 1990s. Labor unions most prominently represented are the United Automobile Workers (aka the International Union, United Automobile, Aircraft, and Agricultural Implement Workers of America), the United Steel Workers of America, the International Longshoremen's and Warhousemen's Union, the Communications Workers of America, the National Maritime Union, and the American Federation of Teachers.
did.physloc: Materials stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact tamiment.wagner@library.nyu.edu at least two business days prior to research visit.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Copyright status is unknown. Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the:
Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012
Phone: (212) 998-2630
Fax: (212) 995-4225
E-mail: tamiment.wagner@library.nyu.edu

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: One half linear foot of official labor union, U.S. Department of Labor, and outside left publications have been separated to the library's serial and pamphlet holdings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two series: I, Processed Materials (arranged alphabetically); II, Unprocessed Materials.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The 1970s and 1980s saw widespread deindustrialization and a worsening political and legal climate for organized labor in the United States. In response to these conditions, and to the perceived inadequacy of union leaders' responses to these challenges, rank and file caucuses arose in many unions and localities. A large role was played by former student activists of the New Left, many of whom had found their way into numerous small and often short-lived communist, socialist, Trotskyist and Maoist organizations.

The Prometheus Research Library assembled and donated this collection. The Prometheus Research Library is a research facility for Marxist studies and the central reference archive of the Spartacist League of the U.S. The Spartacist League of the U.S. is a Trotskyist organization and section of the International Communist League (Fourth International). The Prometheus Research Library’s collection is centered upon the work and interests of the American Communist and Trotskyist movements.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: No original order was apparent in the collection upon receipt. In Series II: Unprocessed Materials, materials were grouped into folders and original folder titles were maintained when possible.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This collection principally consists of printed ephemera from left rank and file caucuses within labor unions in the United States and other Anglophone countries from the late 1960s through the early 1990s. Labor unions most prominently represented are the United Automobile Workers (aka the International Union, United Automobile, Aircraft, and Agricultural Implement Workers of America), the United Steelworkers of America, the International Longshoremen's and Warhousemen's Union, the Communications Workers of America, the National Maritime Union, and the American Federation of Teachers. Strongly represented locals include UAW Local 600 (Dearborn, Michigan), UAW Local 1364 (Fremont, California), and ILWU Local 6 (Bay Area). There are also materials from some radical political parties that play a leading role in this activity, and from labor organizations they founded, as well as subject files.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Gift of Prometheus Research Library (New York), 1997.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Left Labor Caucuses; TAM 192; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Related collections at Tamiment include Communications Workers of America Records (WAG 124), Communications Workers of America Printed Ephemera Collection (PE 023), Communications Workers of America Oral History Collection (OH 026), and National Maritime Union of America Printed Ephemera Collection (PE 008).

Collections relating to the International Union, United Automobile, Aerospace and Agricultural Implement Workers of America and its locals, including Local 600, can be found at the Walter P. Reuther Library at Wayne State University. Materials related to the United Steelworkers of America can be found in the United Steelworkers of America Archives at Pennsylvania State University.
